docs.lead_paragraph: Insufficient Medicaid payments have left many of the state’s hospitals in dire financial shape, with several running a deficit for years, according to a report released last month by the State Legislature.

headline.print_headline: Medicaid Shortfall Hurts Hospitals, Report Finds

docs.snippet: Insufficient Medicaid payments have left many of the state’s hospitals in dire financial shape, with several running a deficit for years, according to a report released last month by the State Legislature.

docs.lead_paragraph: When the author learned that her children’s former baby sitter had been arrested for assaulting two elderly men in her care, she needed some answers. For starters, what is trust?
docs.snippet: When the author learned that her children’s former baby sitter had been arrested for assaulting two elderly men in her care, she needed some answers. For starters, what is trust?

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Health Care Problem? Check the American Psyche'' (Economic View, Dec. 31), about public opposition to a single-payer health care system: Perhaps the biggest barrier to adopting this system here, despite the many advantages, is that private insurance companies and other interests profiting handsomely from the current system's myriad plans and complexity will work very hard to defeat any proposal for change to such a plan. We saw this before with President Bill Clinton's proposal, which did not even cut the private insurers out of the picture.

headline.main: A Single-Payer Path For American Health Care?

docs.abstract: Letters on December 31 Economic View column on public opposition to single-payer health care; Mark Joy, M D says that private insurance companies profit from current system; Lawrence K Harris, M D holds that long waiting lists outweigh cost benefits to patients; Ralph M Segall points out failures of single-payer model in other fields; Seymour Herschberg M D calls for more testing and technology (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: What New Yorkers saw in Eliot Spitzer’s first week in office was a governor in full trumpet about how to overhaul their state government.
docs.snippet: What New Yorkers saw in Eliot Spitzer’s first week in office was a governor in full trumpet about how to overhaul their state government.

docs.lead_paragraph: The other day, we asked Empire Zone readers to give advice to New York's new governor. There were suggestions to improve the upstate economy, provide affordable housing and health care for all, reform workers compensation and workplace safety, impose term limits on legislators, reduce pollution, raise the minimum wage, repeal the Rockefeller-era drug laws, pass legislation allowing same-sex marriage or civil unions, and more. Following is an edited selection."As a student, my main concern is college tuition," writes the commenter Amy. "I believe that Governor Spitzer should investigate and take a look at how college funds are truly used. As a student I am extremely disappointed in the education I am paying to receive, and also extremely broke."

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Eliot Spitzer named four staff members, three of whom have been close advisers and a fourth, Debra Bachrach, who has been a lawyer and lobbyist. Ms. Bachrach was named deputy commissioner of the Office of Health Insurance Programs and also the state’s Medicaid director. The move follows his appointment of Lorraine A. Cortés-Vázquez, a former Cablevision lobbyist, as his secretary of state. Among the other appointees was Lloyd Constantine, who served as co-chairman of his transition team. He was named special counsel. Also appointed were two people who served under Mr. Spitzer while he was attorney general: Joe Baker was named assistant deputy secretary for health and human services, and Marlene Turner was named chief of staff.

docs.lead_paragraph: YONKERS, Jan. 4 — Dr. Leandro Lozada was the kind of pediatrician parents adored. Five days a week, he would leave his comfortable neighborhood here and travel to his private medical practice in a poor section of the Bronx, where he sometimes treated people who had no insurance and occasionally handed out free medication.

headline.main: Grief and Many Questions After a Pediatrician’s Killing

docs.lead_paragraph: Deval L. Patrick, the first Democratic governor of Massachusetts in 16 years and its first black governor, promised far-reaching changes in attitude and policy.
